b'Meet AJ Steinbring (right), administrative assistant, Sourcing at General Mills. Like many others this year, AJ had to adjust her wedding plans and honeymoon due to the pandemic, but she and her wife didn\xe2\x80\x99t let it ruin their big moment. The couple changed their wedding location to the top of a parking ramp overlooking Target Field in downtown Minneapolis, and then pivoted their honeymoon from a European tour to a tour of the four corners of Minnesota. 

\xe2\x80\x9cIt wasn\xe2\x80\x99t our dream wedding, but it was perfect because at the end of the day, I officially became Stacey\xe2\x80\x99s wife.\xe2\x80\x9d 

When asked what she loves most about her job at General Mills, Steinbring said, \xe2\x80\x9cI love working for a Minnesota-based company that not only feeds the world but also genuinely cares about sustainable agriculture and takes a strong stance on supporting human rights issues like racial equality and LGBTQ rights. I am able to bring my whole authentic self to work each and every day for the first time in my career, which in turn has allowed me to flourish in my role and build genuine relationships with my co-workers.\xe2\x80\x9d #generalmillslife'
b"Happy Thanksgiving! However you're celebrating this year, we hope your day is filled with joy, gratitude and good food. :red_heart_selector:"

b'The family of Laura Rott, runner-up in the first Pillsbury Bake-Off Contest in 1949, recently donated a vintage electric range and apron from the contest to the General Mills Archives. Learn more about Rott\xe2\x80\x99s story and the historic donation on our blog (link in bio, navigate to history section).'

b'Leah Martin had always dreamed of meeting tennis superstar Serena Williams, but never believed it would actually happen. But after she saw @wheatiescereal\xe2\x80\x99s sweepstakes with the chance to win a virtual meeting with Williams, she took her shot at the opportunity. And she won! See what Martin had to say about the once in a lifetime opportunity (link in bio).'

b"While the holidays will look different this year, General Mills is here to help you find ways to celebrate. 

From catering more intimate dinners and learning new cooking skills to starting new traditions, our brands have the solutions you need to make cooking and baking easy, affordable and full of joy this holiday season. 

Visit our blog to see what our brands are dishing up (link in bio). And head to our Story to let us know what support you're looking for this holiday season."

b'On this Veterans Day in the U.S., we honor and salute our employees who have served in the U.S. military, and those who continue to serve, for their admirable service and sacrifice. We also give special recognition to the "force behind the force" - our employees who have family members serving in the military. 

Pictured here is Emily Thomas, vice president, managing director of our Natural & Organic operating unit, with her husband Matt Thomas, Lieutenant Colonel in the Minnesota Air National Guard, and their kids.

Emily told us, "I'm incredibly proud of my husband and all of those who serve or have served. Families play such a critical role as well, so we send our thoughts to all of those who are missing a loved one this holiday season."
 
At General Mills, we\xe2\x80\x99re proud to support veterans and their families with the Veterans Network, a special community that provides mentorship for veteran applicants and new hires, ongoing support that\xe2\x80\x99s tailor-made for veteran employees and their families, and volunteer work with community programs.
 
How are you celebrating and honoring Veterans Day? #generalmillslife'

b'Meet Janavi Kumar, digital senior sensory scientist at General Mills. Like many others, Kumar has had to adapt to working from home during the pandemic \xe2\x80\x93 shown here in her home office setup that helps keep her moving throughout the day.
 
Sensory scientists help invoke, measure and analyze sensory perception to food, and help translate those into remarkable product experiences for consumers. In her role, Kumar focuses on experimentation with digital tools and new technologies to enhance the way we collect and utilize sensory and consumer data.
 
She told us, \xe2\x80\x9cI love that I get to work for a company that has innovation in its DNA, and in a role where I can bring my passion for experimentation, and working on cutting-edge research, everyday!\xe2\x80\x9d #generalmillslife'

b'Tennis stars from around the world, including @k1ngkyrg1os @andymurray and @sofia.kenin are giving back to local food banks with the #MessFreeChallenge \xe2\x80\x93 a challenge to play tennis one-handed with no spills while eating the newly launched @OldElPaso Tortilla Pocket. From Australia to Europe and the Americas, the donations in each region took off, with 100,000 products/meals being donated. See more of the global match on our blog. (link in bio)'

b"The @Bettycrocker #TasteNotWaste Challenge is back! 

Did you know that 40% of food that's brought home ends up uneaten and in landfills, costing a family of four more than $1,500 each year? 

From properly storing your food so it keeps longer, to using what you have on hand, you can positively impact that number. Share what you're doing to reduce food waste at home with the hashtag #TasteNotWaste. And discover a new set of easy and fun tips on our blog (link in bio)."

b'Congratulations to Rachael Wooden, manager of our manufacturing plant in Albuquerque, New Mexico, who was named an honoree of the Albuquerque Business First Diverse Business Leader awards. 

Rachael says, \xe2\x80\x9cI am humbled and grateful to be selected as an honoree for Diverse Business Leader. The work to drive real systematic change, inclusion, and equity is not easy. Many trailblazers in history experienced immense turmoil in the pursuit of justice. It is my obligation and in my heart to help protect the humanity of people. If I can inspire, lead change, drop kick barriers, and use my voice for equality, that\xe2\x80\x99s exactly what I intend to do. Thank you Albuquerque Business First for this incredible honor and for using your platform to elevate fellow leaders and the POWER of diversity.\xe2\x80\x9d #generalmillslife

b'Meet Joel Stamp, transportation manager and president of the Veterans Network at General Mills. Stamp is also an active member of the Minnesota Army National Guard. From March 26 to June 28, he was activated as the National Guard logistics liaison to Minnesota Governor Tim Walz\xe2\x80\x99 Operational Planning Team for Critical Care Supplies. In this role, he used his logistics expertise from General Mills to assist the state in procuring more than $110 million worth of Personal Protective Equipment. 

On May 28, after the death of George Floyd in Minneapolis, Stamp shifted his focus to civil unrest. He spent 12 days conducting logistical life support activities for more than 7,500 soldiers in the Twin Cities. 

He told us, \xe2\x80\x9cGeneral Mills was very supportive during this time. Having co-workers reach out to thank me for what I was doing and make sure my family and I were doing well was really nice. It was great to see messages from our senior leaders about what was going on at the company, and what actions General Mills was taking to address the civil unrest and to help keep our employees safe during this pandemic. It really illustrated the true generosity of the company.\xe2\x80\x9d #generalmillslife'

b"For nearly 125 days, Mike Klaas (right), region sales director at General Mills, has done something to put a smile on the face of someone in need. Since COVID-19 hit, Klaas has collected more than $18,000 via a GoFundMe fundraising page. It's part of his \xe2\x80\x9cGiving is Living\xe2\x80\x9d initiative to help fulfill basic needs for people living in Northwest Arkansas, where he lives and works. For his outstanding efforts, he was recently recognized with a General Mills Global Volunteer Award.\n\nHe told us, \xe2\x80\x9cThe concept is simple: create a crowdfunded donation page, do good in the community, then share back via social media where the money is going. This way people can keep up with activities on a daily basis, learn about different local organizations, provide input on where the dollars go, etc\xe2\x80\xa6It\xe2\x80\x99s truly a blessing to be part of this.\xe2\x80\x9d #generalmillslife"

b'Meet Rafaela Guadalupe (@rafa_guadalupe), senior R&D process engineer in our Melbourne, Australia office. Rafaela recently made this video to express her gratitude for the impact General Mills has had on her life, both personally and professionally. She told us, \xe2\x80\x9cThere is a culture of belonging in the company, which empowers me to be my authentic self and share my truth. I hope that, through this video, I can shed a light of motivation and inspiration for the women in the workforce, who might face a lot of challenges through their careers, but are not willing to give up.\xe2\x80\x9d #generalmillslife'

b"Since Kennedy McCormick was seven years old, she\xe2\x80\x99s asked for the same thing for her birthday: boxes of cereal to donate to @feedingtampabay\xe2\x80\x99s #CerealForSummer food program. This year, for her 14th birthday, Kennedy couldn't host her cereal drive because of COVID-19, so she put on a virtual food drive instead, raising $3,000 for Feeding Tampa Bay. Our friends at @cheerios found out about all her hard work and surprised Kennedy this morning with a donation of 48,000 boxes of Apple Cinnamon Cheerios \xe2\x80\x93 that's two semi-trucks full and the equivalent of about 500,000 meals. Congratulations Kennedy, Feeding Tampa Bay and thank you for everything you\xe2\x80\x99ve done! Read the full story, and see what Kennedy had to say about the surprise donation on our blog (link in bio)."
b'Thank you, from the bottom of our :red_heart_selector:, to all our employees showing up every day to make food the world loves - and needs.'

b'Meet James Momon, senior director of global inclusion at General Mills. James also co-leads the Minnesota Corporate and Community Coalition, which is comprised of Minnesota corporate leaders working to drive systemic change and leverage their scale to support the communities who\xe2\x80\x99ve been impacted by racial and social injustice. \n\nJames told us, "Leading global inclusion at General Mills has always been truly rewarding but in this moment never has my work had more purpose. In light of the recent tragedy involving George Floyd here in Minneapolis, there is an urgency to the work we\xe2\x80\x99re doing. Creating a culture of belonging for our employees everyday inside of General Mills and creating meaningful change to heal the wounds of systemic racism and social injustice in our communities. We have a lot of work to do and my kids are at the heart of my WHY every day." #generalmillslife'

b"We're proud to raise the Progress Pride Flag at our World Headquarters in Minneapolis, Minnesota today. It's a symbol of our unwavering support and allyship for the LGBTQ+, Transgender, and Black and Brown communities. It also represents our commitment to a culture of inclusion and belonging at General Mills.\n\nWhile our Pride celebrations look different this year, employees near our World Headquarters were still able to come together for our first-ever Pride Ride \xe2\x80\x93 a car parade through our campus, allowing employees and their loved ones to celebrate safely together to see the flag waving proudly. See more on our blog (link in bio). Happy #Pride Month! :rainbow: #generalmillslife"

b'General Mills employees across the globe are taking courageous actions today to help our communities rebuild and to help drive lasting change for social and racial justice. All employees are encouraged to take part in our #DayofCourageousAction in a way that is meaningful to them, whether it be volunteering in their community, donating to a non-profit or having courageous conversations with their friends and family.

Employees near our WHQ, including our Chairman and CEO Jeff Harmening, came together this morning to assemble 10,000 community kits and provide donations for our local Minneapolis community.

The challenge before us is significant. It can\xe2\x80\x99t and it won\xe2\x80\x99t be solved in a single day, but our commitment is unwavering.

#DayofCourageousAction #GeneralMillsLife'

b'The current civil unrest began in Minneapolis. But it spread to other cities across our country and across the world because it\xe2\x80\x99s NOT just one community\xe2\x80\x99s problem.

We recognize systematic injustice and racism still exist.

We understand the magnitude of the challenge in front of us - to create a just and inclusive culture - is significant.

We come to this moment in our history, humbly, fully realizing there are no easy solutions. But we also come with an unwavering commitment to find answers.

We need both courageous conversations and courageous actions. 
We have a lot of work to do. Learn about some initial steps we are taking as a company at the link in our bio.'

b"In the wake of George Floyd\xe2\x80\x99s death in our hometown of Minneapolis, Minnesota, our Chairman and CEO Jeff Harmening shared how General Mills is committing to convene courageous conversations and take courageous actions.

Because collectively we know it\xe2\x80\x99s not just about what you say\xe2\x80\xa6 but about what you do.

We\xe2\x80\x99re focusing our initial actions in five areas:

Relief: We have mobilized a donation to those families most directly impacted by the destruction in the Twin Cities. We are providing access to food and household supplies. And we are working to create pop-up food pantries to bring nourishment and stability. 
Recovery: We are helping with the recovery, joining with other foundations and companies to help the many neighborhood businesses that were damaged or destroyed.
Convening: We are also exploring ways to help convene courageous conversations throughout our community and our country. Because the true challenge before us can\xe2\x80\x99t be solved by writing checks and walking away. 
Partnering: And, because we are stronger together, we're actively working to build a broad coalition that includes many of our corporate peers here in the Twin Cities \xe2\x80\x93 partners who share our bedrock commitment to diversity and inclusion. 
Voicing: Lastly, we know some solutions simply can\xe2\x80\x99t come from us. And so we are also looking at where we as a corporate citizen might lend our voice and support to possible policy and legislative action.

The magnitude of the challenge in front of us - to create a just and inclusive culture - is significant.

We all have a lot of work to do.
(Photo: Hanna Johnson)"

b'Meet Andrea Espach, associate creative director at @bluebuffalo. Andrea co-produced and co-creative directed Blue Buffalo\'s recent ad "Another Morning," which highlights BLUE employees and their beloved pets enjoying special moments together at home. Andrea told us, "The BLUE team is family. We\xe2\x80\x99ve shared a lot of significant moments together\xe2\x80\x94professionally and personally. I believe we were able to tell an emotional and compelling story that every family can relate to." :blue_heart: #generalmillslife'

b"Want to be part of a virtual film club? @haagendazsuk is bringing the magic of the cinema directly to your sofa with \xe2\x80\x9cSecret Sofa\xe2\x80\x9d - a weekly film series featuring thematic pairings of H\xc3\xa4agen-Dazs ice cream. Follow along @haagendazsuk to learn more and sign up. #haagindoors 
#Repost @haagendazsuk
\xe3\x83\xbb\xe3\x83\xbb\xe3\x83\xbb
Time to bring a bit of H\xc3\xa4ag-Indoors magic to this lockdown! In partnership with our friends @secret_cinema we\xe2\x80\x99re excited to bring you virtually the best film club in the world, #SecretSofa complete with the perfect pairing of H\xc3\xa4agen-Dazs delivered to you.
Over the next 8 weeks, we will bring you Secret Worlds you may have loved, may have missed or which might not have happened yet, directly to your home.
We're talking everything from additional storylines to character and costume suggestions to era-defining music and activities to food and drink ideas (and lots of ice cream obviously). At 7.30pm (BST) on Friday, thousands of us hit play at the same time to watch some of the greatest films together.
The first Secret Sofa film is being announced tomorrow! Keep following our stories this week or sign up to get on the mailing list for access (link in bio).
\xe2\x80\x8b#HaagIndoors #SecretSofa #SecretCinema"

b"#Repost @btfe\n\xe3\x83\xbb\xe3\x83\xbb\xe3\x83\xbb\nIn celebration of Teacher Appreciation Week, we're excited to partner with Chance The Rapper to host the first-ever Twilight Awards, broadcasted live on Instagram at 7 p.m. CST May 6, 7 and 8. During these special shows, Chance The Rapper will surprise and award teachers, schools and nonprofits a total of $300,000 on behalf of Box Tops for Education. Follow @chancetherapper and tune in this week to watch The Twilight Awards and find out which teachers Chance The Rapper is celebrating! For more details, go to btfe.com/chance or check out the link in bio. #teacherappreciationweek #twilightawards"
b'May the 4th Be With You! Coming to a cereal aisle near you later this summer. #maythe4thbewithyou #starwarsday'

b'Meet Rinku Malhotra (left), advanced analyst on our HR Tech & Solutions team, based in Minneapolis, Minnesota. When Rinku heard about the need for face masks at North Memorial Health Hospital, he got to work. Rinku is using his 3D printer to create face shields and mask straps to donate to health care workers. Last week, he reached his goal of printing 100 shields, but he\xe2\x80\x99s not stopping there. Rinku plans to print and donate shields for as long as his supplies allow.\n\nRinku told us, \xe2\x80\x9cMy dad had heart surgery at North Memorial in 2005. I was 15 at the time, and it was an incredibly impactful moment in my life. What I remember most is the care and support my family received from the doctors and hospital staff in our time of uncertainty. Since then, I have wanted to give back to the hospital that saved my dad\xe2\x80\x99s life. Now with the shields, I saw an opportunity to help the hospital staff in their moment of need. Giving back means so much to me and my family.\xe2\x80\x9d #generalmillslife'

b'Meet Chelsey Marshall, marketing manager for commercial restaurants in our Convenience & Foodservice business. To support restaurants during this time of COVID-19, Chelsey recently helped launch a program called #TogetherforTakeout. In the program, each General Mills employee on the Foodservice team can choose their favorite restaurant to order takeout from during the month of April and receive a reimbursement for that meal from General Mills.\n\nChelsey told us, \xe2\x80\x9cThis past month has been extremely challenging for the restaurant industry as many restaurants have had to quickly shift service models to takeout and delivery. However, they have brought forward creative solutions that are helping them to keep their doors open. Restaurant owners are remarkable people and the resilience of the industry is shining through these dark times. It has been an honor and humbling experience to help roll out #TogetherforTakeout for our team and restaurants in our communities. This program is another example of why I\xe2\x80\x99m proud to work for General Mills!\xe2\x80\x9d #generalmillslife'

b"Especially during this time of the COVID-19 pandemic, we're committed to doing everything we can to support our employees and communities around the world. The General Mills Foundation is proud to commit an additional $5 million in charitable grants to ensure the most vulnerable children have access to meals amid school and community program closures. General Mills is also providing enhanced benefits for our plant employees, including a daily bonus, and an opportunity for corporate employees to provide temporary work at manufacturing plants. Learn more on our blog (link in bio)."

b'Our top priority is the health and safety of our employees and serving our consumers through this challenging time. Thank you to all our colleagues across the globe - from those working inside our manufacturing plants, to making sure schools can serve grab-and-go meals, to those ensuring our products are available to consumers, and more - for your unwavering dedication to our purpose of making food the world loves. :red_heart_selector:'

b'You might say Josie Titcomb and Kurt Bogdahn are lucky in love.:four_leaf_clover: After an extra sweet proposal in 2018, thanks to a box of @luckycharms, the couple officially tied the knot this past December. And Lucky Charms played a big role in their big day! From a custom embroidered bowl of cereal in Josie\xe2\x80\x99s dress, to Lucky Charms toppings at their hot chocolate bar, it\xe2\x80\x99s safe to say it was a truly magical day. :rainbow: Congrats, Josie and Kurt!'

b'Meet JP Del Carmen (front row, second from right), a senior brand manager on our cereal team in Toronto, Canada. :Canada: Here he\xe2\x80\x99s pictured with his team during their \xe2\x80\x9c21 Days of Cheer\xe2\x80\x9d campaign this past year, encouraging Canadians to join @cheeriosca on its mission to bring Cheer to the world!\n\nWhen asked what he enjoys most about his role, JP said, \xe2\x80\x9cI love my job because every day is an opportunity for me to be an entrepreneur who builds purpose-led brands while working with some of the best and brightest in the industry.\xe2\x80\x9d #generalmillslife'

b'The refrigerated dough business started in 1930 when Kentucky baker, Lively Willoughby, developed the tube can to keep his biscuit dough fresh before delivering it to local homes. @pillsbury purchased the business in 1951 and 10 years later, Pillsbury\xe2\x80\x99s Crescent Rolls were introduced for 29 cents a can! :croissant: #tbt'

b'More than 2,400 people just attended the 30th annual Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Holiday Breakfast in our hometown of Minneapolis, Minnesota. This year, the keynote was from Eric H. Holder Jr., former U.S. attorney general. We\xe2\x80\x99re proud to be part of this event. Watch the replay at http://MLKbreakfast.com #MLKBreakfastMN #generalmillslife'

b'Meet Michelle Meade, a field selling assistant at General Mills, and active volunteer. For several years, Meade has traveled to Africa to provide hands-on support to women and children in need. Her work in Zambia began after her brother, Dr. Tim Meade, founded @tinytimandfriends, an organization that provides treatment, care and support to HIV positive women and children. After the unexpected loss of her brother in 2016, Meade and her family kept his dream alive through their work with TTF. For her efforts, Meade received a certificate of merit, a medal and a $500 grant from the General Mills Foundation, which was donated to TTF. Read her full story on our blog (link in bio). #generalmillslife'

b'BuzzBee and the Doughboy arrived in Washington, D.C. today! They\xe2\x80\x99re there with our CEO, Jeff Harmening, to celebrate the launch of the Consumer Brands Association (CBA), formerly known as the Grocery Manufacturers Association. Harmening serves as the chairman of the board of directors for the CBA. #ConsumerBrands'

b'It\xe2\x80\x99s time to rise and sparkle! Trix is serving up even more fun and fruity flavors to the breakfast table with its new, hair-raising cereal: Trix @trolls with marshmallows! \nReady to rock out? :guitar: Boxes are now available nationwide.'

b'Meet Brianna Frederick, senior data scientist at General Mills. Here she\xe2\x80\x99s up to bat in front of the Wheaties wall at a Minnesota @twins game she attended with her team and some General Mills leadership. :baseball: When asked what she enjoys most about her role, Brianna said, \xe2\x80\x9cI love that I get to have a tangible impact on vital initiatives throughout General Mills that touch all areas of the business. Not only do I get to dig in and use our wealth of data to answer key questions and help shape our future as an organization, but I also get to influence staffing and development of our data science team.\xe2\x80\x9d #generalmillslife'
b'From our General Mills family to yours, we wish you a happy new year filled with the people and food you love. :red_heart_selector:'
